title: Broke, Ashamed, and Denied: What It’s Really Like to Apply for Social Services in 2025

content: What is a person worth? Who is worthy? Of help, of love, of existence?

Many philosophers and poets have answered those questions far better than I ever could. But the idea has been swirling around in my mind ever since the Orange Leader’s Big Beautiful Bill was first getting press.

In all the media coverage, we heard a lot of talk about cuts to Medicaid and SNAP services, and work requirements being added. All the while the GOPs on the hill talked about Americans in a horrible way, accusing those who need such benefits as being lazy, (among the nicer names the GOP has for some Americans).
“They should just pick themselves up from their bootstraps,” we hear all the damn time from the hard heads and hearts of the Trump regime.

By the way, I did a little Googlin’ on that phrase, “Pick yourself up from your bootstraps.” It originated in the 19th century. It was a metaphor for something futile, for someone who was trying to do a preposterous task without help.

content: Because if you think about it literally, it’s impossible to lift yourself off the ground by your bootstraps!  Amazing how it’s morphed into a phrase used to belittle people who don’t have many choices or advantages, as if they’re somehow lazy for not being able to do the impossible.
Another aspect of the national dialogue on social safety nets is that acquiring services is way too easy.

It seems the people elected to represent us, at least on the Red side, think all a person has to do is ask and the government hands over whatever they need. Well, at the risk of looking like a lazy, good-for-nothing scab on the system, I’m going to tell you a little about a recent experience with social services.

At the beginning of 2025, I found myself underemployed. I’m a freelance writer. Besides sporadic writing for health periodicals, I also worked as a contributing editor for an online publication that was my major bread and butter. In mid-2024, this publication changed how they were compensating writers, and I went from getting a flat fee every month (it wasn’t much, but I could count on it), to having to bill them for every article, video, and social media post I created.

content: Then, the main project I spearheaded for this publication for five years was unceremoniously cancelled, cutting my pay by $1,000 per month. I started trying to drum up some other writing work.
I struggled hard for three (or so) months. Friends were kind and loaned me money and my mother was very supportive, but I was in deep shame about my situation.

It truly felt like cosmic punishment. For what, I’m not sure. Perhaps the fact that I am an artist with an unconventional life. Maybe the Universe is still mad that I didn’t finish college. It could be payback for the 10 months my addictions got the better of me, three years ago (I’ve been chemically temperate since February 2024).
Whatever the reason, I was in a crisis.
One day, a lifelong friend made the suggestion: Why don’t you ask the state for help?
“There are a lot of benefits that you probably qualify for,” he said. “I know that it’s hard to ask, but I promise you that you’ll feel such relief to have assistance until you’re back on your feet.”

content: I had to admit I needed help. So the next day, I went online and started the application for food assistance and a one-time payment to help me pay rent.

In this country, when you apply for social services, you have to prove you have actual need. You have to prove you’re not trying to cheat the system. I had to ask my landlord for a letter stating I was in arrears for back rent. I had to give these strangers in the government access to my piddly bank accounts so they could see for themselves how much money I don’t have. I had to prove I own no assets: house, car, property, etc.
As far as these safety nets are concerned, a person in need is guilty until proven innocent: A crook until they prove themselves not to be.

I was approved right away for a one-time food assistance benefit, so I received a SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) debit card for a few hundred dollars. That was super helpful, but there are odd rules one has to follow.

content: For example, a person on SNAP can’t buy a rotisserie chicken, or any cooked food from a grocery store. Something like a rotisserie chicken is considered a luxury, and the United States can’t have needy people enjoy conveniences like the rest of society. Needy people don’t deserve convenience, let alone the luxury of a cooked chicken.
The payment for my rent was another story.

I was denied and was told to call and speak to someone. When I called, I was put on hold while music was playing (there’s a composer in the world who writes that annoying music and gets paid!). There’s no call-back option, so I had to stay on the phone. Because of the music, and fear I’d miss the person who finally answers, I couldn’t do anything but wait.

After hours of being on hold, a person finally spoke. After looking up my case, they found that some of the bank paperwork I submitted was hard to read, so I had to resubmit. Instead of informing me the paperwork was faulty, I’d been simply denied.

content: Basically, I had to start the whole process over.

After days of again being on hold with the benefits office, I realized I could spend this time sitting on hold or I could look for a job. I couldn’t do both. I started looking for any kind of work –  retail, secretarial, checking LinkedIn several times a day.
Finally, I got hired as a creative and I’m working steadily. I’m still poor, but my rent is paid and I have food in my fridge.
I never received any financial help from the state. My application was denied a second time, and the state closed the case. It was too challenging and humiliating for me to pursue it further.
And that’s the point. The government makes it a horrible experience and super awful so that many people give up trying.
That was just my experience, and I’m only one person. I can only imagine what a family who is in need of help has to go through.

content: Who deserves help?  At what point would my need have made me worthy?

Financial help, SNAP, unemployment, Medicare and Medicaid d — these benefits are there to help us when life has made things extra arduous. They’re available to anyone who needs help, if you can prove you’re worthy.
And soon, because of our Orange Leader’s Big Beautiful Bill and the horrible representatives who backed it, people needing help will have more flaming governmental hoops to jump through to get help.

All because the MAGA regime thinks American citizens asking for help deserve humiliation and punishment. We must prove our own worth in order to be Americans. And if we’re not worthy, denial of services could be just the beginning.
The government could decide you should be detained, imprisoned, and deported. It sounds nuts, but it’s happening right now.
Maya Angelou once said, “You alone are enough. You have nothing to prove to anyone.” I guess in the United States, that sentiment is too “woke.”
